What I've noticed is that most of the negative reviews concern the economic side of the game, not the gameplay itself.
I'm a big boy who grew up playing CCGs, so I'm aware of the expenses that come with this hobby.

In my opinion, it's the best digital CCG on the market right now.

A spectacular game, both in terms of mechanics and visuals... I can't stand manga... and this game is the only case where that doesn't bother me. The design of the cards, boards, characters and effects accompanying the game are world-class.

As an MTGA veteran with a nearly complete collection, I've now completely switched to Shadowverse.
What this game gives me is the feeling of playing with an opponent, not with the limitations imposed by an algorithm and absurd matchmaking.

The greatest satisfaction for me in these types of games comes from building decks; in MTG, I achieved top Mythic levels using only my own builds.
Deck building here gives me immense satisfaction, which translates into an advantage over a less experienced opponent with a deck they haven't explored enough.

I have several hundred hours of playtime on my iPad, and unfortunately, I can't link my account to my Steam because I created a Steam account on release day and then forgot and created another one on my tablet.
So remember, Steam only allows you to link only one Shadowverse account, and it's permanent.

The economic situation is similar to other CCGs; you should expect to spend around 100-200$ when a new expansion is released to maintain your collection.

I'm not a F2P player who spends weeks playing the same deck online. I need cards to build my own decks, so I'm paying for my enjoyment.

Playing regularly, I managed to build a 100% collection based on in-game bonuses and purchasing gems when new expansions were released.

I never played the original Shadowverse. All of the negative reviews I've seen from this game have been from people  who have claiming it isn't as "f2p friendly." While that might be true, as someone who has played a lot of Magic Arena and early master duel, I can say that it is much more f2p friendly than both of those games. You get a free pack on login every day. They consistently have events and other ways to get resources along with dailies. The meta right now appears fairly balanced. While you might not be able to make a fully meta top-tier deck in every archetype as a f2p player at the start you also can't do that in any other free tcg game at the moment that I'm aware of. (At least not the big ones). This game comparably appears to have the quickest entry into competitive play without breaking the bank, and even if you don't want to play competitively there are plenty of casual ways to play and still make enjoyable decks. I still play magic on paper, but I'll never go back to Arena after playing this.

If you want to play baby's first TCG, play Pokemon.
If you want to play solitaire/roulette/dice, play Yu-Gi-Oh.
If you want to play a TCG where you'll never financially recover from, play Magic the Gathering.
But if you want to play a card game with beautiful art, aggressive monetization and terrible blancing, play Shadowverse.

The game is fun, well-polished, and has plenty of close matches that keep you on the edge of your seat. However, the monetization can be questionable.

Pros:

-Really fun gameplay mechanics; Evo and Super-Evo are game-changers.

-Many decks to choose from, offering a wide variety of playstyles.

-Everything is well-polished — the art, UI, and voice acting are top-tier for a card game.

-The park feature adds a social element, making the game feel less lonely.

-Amazing paid cosmetics if that’s your thing.

-Daily free card packs.

Cons:

-Monetization is questionable. You cannot mill cards unless you have duplicates, which makes it very hard for new players to build decks. Top-ups may feel almost necessary.

-Legendary cards are expensive — 3,500 to craft one, so it takes a lot of saving.

-The gap between free-to-play and whales is quite large.

-Minor nitpick: the art style of each card varies noticeably. You can easily tell that different artists drew them. While nearly all cards are beautiful, the lack of a consistent art direction can be slightly frustrating (for comparison, card games like Gwent or LoR have very cohesive art styles).

Overall, this is an excellent card game. New players and free-to-play users will need patience at first, but once you get started, it’s incredibly fun.

This game has a whole lot of "my deck decided that the match is over now", where drawing a card or waiting on a card just becomes an enrage timer where the amount of time is unknown.

I don't mean simply powerful cards that integrate well with the rest of your deck and depend heavily on how well you played.  I mean literal match ending cards that invalidate many types of decks from being viable in this game and just make whoever used it first likely win.

It's not even always about damage, some of them just win the match.  Even if they're at full health and have an invincibility bubble on their leader, it will instantly kill them.  That aspect of the game is extremely uncompelling, because there isn't some decision you can make to deal with it, the game just decides that the match is over and there is no satisfying resolution in terms of decision making that gives the player agency over it.

I think they wanted a game with shorter matches to make it more mobile/on-the-go friendly and to optimize the matchmaker.  Shorter matches = healthier matchmaker.  Problem is, they forgot to design a game for shorter matches, where it's part of the design philosophy from the start so it feels like an afterthought.

Despite that, because not everyone decides to put those cards in their deck, you can have many enjoyable matches so long as you stay out of the higher ranks.  If you are the kind of person that chases the meta in any game, this game will probably disappoint you.  One upside is that these game ending cards make it kind of easy even for casual players to get some wins whether they built a great deck or not.

Additionally, what people say about people just taking turns clearing each others boards every turn is generally true.  You have to build a deck that minimizes your attrition while either buying you time for a game ending card or make sure to integrate aggressive cards that can both clear the board and attack their leader.  That cards have health/defense values is almost irrelevant in most cases, because the cards just get disappeared every turn.  Banish, destroy, infinite damage, deal an amount of damage that's the same as the health it has!  You name it, they've got some version under a fancy name, rebranded.

In general, this game has several rather unsatisfying (many would read this as "annoying") mechanics that aren't just run of the mill bad, but surprisingly and almost willfully bad.  If you can get past that, the game does have some charm and is very free to play friendly regardless what others say.

I think it might be the closest thing to a Japanese Hearthstone out there and needs some TLC from the developers to course correct some issues.  Without course correction, the player churn may be too high to keep the game relevant for long.

Even though it has many design failings and I wouldn't recommend it to everyone, people do exist that I could recommend this game to with all the necessary caveats.

Look, this gets a negative review from me even BEFORE discussions about monetization. When you make a sequel, it's really for one of two reasons. Reason 1, you need to fix fundamental flaws in the game that can't be fixed in the original. Or Reason 2, you want to take the base concept, and expand on it.

This game does neither. They added a 'super evolve' which could have been part of the base game, and then they just copied every card from the original, word for word, into this one. Which means this must be the hidden Reason 3: They wanted more money.

As someone with nearly 200 hours in the original Shadowverse, I came into Shadowverse Worlds Beyond hoping for a fresh evolution of a great game. And while the new title definitely has potential, I can’t recommend it in its current state.

The biggest disappointment is the monetization. Compared to the original, Worlds Beyond feels significantly more aggressive, pushing players toward spending rather than rewarding gameplay. This is made worse by the removal of one of the best features from the first game: the ability to disenchant your cards to craft the ones you want. In a TCG—a Trading Card Game—being unable to manage your collection and work toward specific builds is extremely frustrating. It makes acquiring the cards you actually want far harder, and it turns what used to be a generous system into a grind-heavy and restrictive one.

Shadowverse Worlds Beyond could become something great, but right now the systems surrounding progression and card acquisition hold it back. As a longtime fan, that’s incredibly disappointing.

LONG RANT BELOW. 

TL;DR: Don't play it, this game is bad.

I have played Shadowverse:  World's Beyond for over 300 hours. I have played since the game's launch, and have hit the highest rank of each set release as of this review (Master in Legends Rise and Infinity Evolved, Grandmaster in Heirs of the Omen and Skybound Dragons).

I can confidently say that this game is not worth your time, and is a skip.

During my time playing I've logged in daily to get the daily free pack, completed every daily mission, grinded ranked religiously each set, and in that time, I've lost all feelings of fun that I've had playing the game.

What ruined the game for me is how Cygames has managed their balance with each set release. From the very start, the game has had stupidly overpowered cards that can instantly end games; from Albert being a board clear with Storm that attacks twice and can deal over half of your health with no set up required, to Cocytus D-Climb instantly killing you in a single turn as soon as the Rune player hit Turn 10, there is no shortage of cards that require no skill or thought to use properly. There are so many cards with ridiculous keywords and mind-boggling stats that strategy feels irrelevant if you can just play cards that practically say "When you play this card, you instantly win the game; ignore how badly you played during the entire rest of the match."

Cygames saw that there were brainless win conditions, and rather than address the issue, they went in the complete opposite direction and introduced more. With the latest expansion Skybound Dragons as an example, there is a new card named Belial that has a gimmick called Skybound Art. You are rewarded for spamming followers that evolve on their own, providing healing and insane tempo at no cost for you, with a card that will clear the board and set a timer on your opponent that will instantly win you the game the moment it goes off. It doesn't help that they've also introduced cards with RNG elements into them like Sandalphon, who will win games for you because you were lucky enough to hit the opponent's face and avoid their followers on board with his RNG effect.

I feel as though the skill floor in the game has gotten worse and worse over time. As of the latest release, the best thing to do every turn is to simply play a card's cost that matches with the turn number. There's no thought or effort that goes into playing a 3 cost on Turn 3, 5 cost on Turn 5, and so on and so forth, and if a board lasts longer than a turn on the field, then the game is over due to the overall damage being way too high. Every game is just a coin flip between you and your opponent to see if they had better value in their hands than you, and it feels stagnant and infuriating when they get a perfect curve with little way to counter it or get tempo back since snowballing advantage is way too easy. Going second is also so much better than going first, since not only do you get access to a coin that refreshes, essentially letting you play your overpowered cards before your opponent can answer them, but you can also access your evolves before the player going first.

If you thought there was hope for Cygames potentially balancing cards, think again. Cygames is notoriously stingy at balancing cards even back in the original Shadowverse, and that philosophy transfers here. They have done almost nothing to address the toxic cards running rampant everywhere since they only look at win rates for decks. If a card is incredibly stupid but the deck it's in has about a 50% win ratio due to the amount of trash players playing it and losing, then they will just let that card ruin the game for all players and pretend that nothing is wrong with it. They also have a bias towards not nerfing cards since if they do, they'll have to give out a small amount of crafting currency to the players that have extra copies; and knowing Cygames, they want to keep their economy as low as possible so that you keep spending your sweet money on their monthly battle passes. The only real nerf they have done as of this review is to a single healing card for Haven, which did almost nothing to address the toxic meta of Heirs of the Omen as the nerf came right at the end of the expansion.

I'm very disappointed in this game and myself for how much time I have spent playing it. I loved the original Shadowverse but got turned off by the rise of power creep in it, and I really wanted this game to do well. When this game was announced, I was genuinely excited to see how this game would evolve over time in the modern era, since I believed that it could really carve out it's own niche out of every other card game. But it seems like Cygames has not learned from their past lessons, and will continue to release yet another card that will instantly win you the game every expansion while stealing your wallet on the side.

I will not be opening this game again, and will be instead devoting my time and energy into other games that want to balance things and make the games feel fair for both players. I hope that Cygames will learn from their mistakes and fix their issues, but I sincerely doubt it based on their track record.

I really wanted to like this game, but it has so many glaring issues that are if anything, worse 4 months after release.

I could rant all day about the bad interactions, card imbalance, Cygames disingenuous practices, class favouritism and stale meta of 3 classes comprising more than 60% of all matches, but it, like this game is just not worth my, or your time.

Not to mention Cygames up to their usual BS with a rigged community event and generally limited rewards from events, dailies and other sources.

The card pool is too small to allow for any real variation between decks, with each archetype having a predictable curve that comes out every match save a little rng on draws.

This causes you to not only have the dice roll on if you get a favourable class match-up, but also the dice roll on your draws, with the small card pool limiting the ability to make any real variation from a core archetype, furthering the repetitive nature of the game.

This current set (Omens) has been the final nail. The biggest issue is the healing/aggro balance, where the meta Haven, Rune and Dragon decks can reliably have 40+ health over the course of a game, which on top of their access to wards and board wipes makes finisher cards like Albert or Roach too expensive to break through, while also being oppressive to other classes, where playing Forest or Portal against Sword, T8/9 is a 12 HP check.

This also raises the issue of coin, going second is a clear advantage, not only having an additional mana early, having curve on evolve unlocks and another additional mana past turn 7. The game is also very reactive, furthering the advantage of going second, allowing you to take tempo before your opponent can evolve, forcing them to miss evolve effects to clear your board.

Overall, I would reccomend you don't play this game, it's just not worth the frustration.

I think the game is absolutely fun, and I really like the visuals. I stayed and played this game for those reasons alone. However, there were many cracks that have shown since launch, and, now, it's time for me to quit.

I'll try to keep it short.

I don't like the economy/monetisation, and the events.

I thought the game's economy wasn't that bad at first. But, now that we're in the third expansion as of this writing, decks feel expensive to make. I don't think the amount of rewards is enough anymore.

As for the events, the Popular Vote event felt rigged. Other comments have explained this, so I'm not going to dive into it. Just note, if that's how players are going to be treated (with events being rigged and their time not being respected), I don't want to be part of it.
Also, my time is not being respected with other events like these stupid chest ones. On top of having to win a match to open a chest, why do those chests appear randomly? I sometimes needed to spend 2-3 hours to open all 5 daily chests. Ridiculous.

There are more problems I have with the game (such as the balancing), but the problems I mentioned were the tipping point.
I want to love this game, but I don't think it'll get better.
I want this game to succeed but the meta for S3 has been by far the worst meta. They want to focus buffing cards but some are just so over tuned that this game isn't enjoyable competitively.

Look, this gets a negative review from me even BEFORE discussions about monetization. When you make a sequel, it's really for one of two reasons. Reason 1, you need to fix fundamental flaws in the game that can't be fixed in the original. Or Reason 2, you want to take the base concept, and expand on it.

This game does neither. They added a 'super evolve' which could have been part of the base game, and then they just copied every card from the original, word for word, into this one. Which means this must be the hidden Reason 3: They wanted more money.

Don't waste your time with this. It doesn't even *look* better than the original. It's as heavy of a no that I can possibly give.

Takes too long to build a deck compared to the original Shadowverse, took 80+ hours to build a single meta deck as a f2p player over the length of maybe a month. I eventually got to Master Rank so I still like the game but it takes way to long to get cards needed for viable decks.

Also does not work with a VPN if that matters.

I tried very hard to like this game, but it just got worse with every set. Awful card designs across the board. Most games are decided by coinflip and skill expression is practically nonexistent. Mechanics like intimidate and extremely overstatted minions make it so the player either has the answer or immediately lose on the spot.

I was 'Beyond' multiple times last season when they first introduced GM, but in retrospect it doesn't feel like an accomplishment at all given how this game works.

For people nostalgic about early hearthstone, don't bother with this.

I'm leaving a negative review for the following reasons:

1. Victory chest reward event doesn't respect the players time. Having a 'chance' for a chest to appear is an extremely frustrating mechanic that is there just to waste the players time. On top of that, the rewards are pretty sub-par for the effort. Either rewards need to go up or getting the chests needs to be easier.

2. Getting leaders from the sets feels extremely bad. Why did they increase the amount to pity AND split the cosmetics for each leader into 3 different parts? Really? If you got everything related to the leaders the increased pity would be somewhat acceptable. Making the daily free pack count towards pity would also be a good start. As is, it feels really unrewarding as a mechanic.

3. Balance is non-existent. They plan to do a balance patch this month but I think it will probably be too little too late. There are way too many singular cards that are just so strong that there really isn't an answer for. A lot of the time it feels like I have zero agency on whether I win or lose a game. If I don't draw X card and my opponent draws Y card I just lose the game instantly. There just isn't much room for any outplay in this game.

The game was fun for a time, but these main issues have just sapped my motivation to play the game.
After 4 sets of worsening gameplay from an already mediocre start, I'm ok with never touching this again
